climbs.name: Rollercoaster
climbs.fa: (TR) Vaino Kodas & Herb Laeger, 1987,  FL: Chris Miller, May 1998

content.description:
Well-protected and varied throughout it's length, this route requires a variety of techniques to succeed - a balancy lieback down low leads to a steep, thin slab in the middle with a thuggy finish over a roof.

Great rock and continuous movement throughout combined with excellent protection make this well-worth doing or even attempting. Four stars out of five.
content.location:
Found just to the left of

Rollerball

on the northwest corner of the formation.

climbs.name: Rollerbrah
climbs.fa: Randy Leavitt, Chris Hubbard and Glenn Svenson, November 2000

content.description: Climb the face between Rollerball and Rollercoaster staying independant of either route.

A start past some horizontals gets you to a ledge with a left-leaning thin crack which thins and dies, with the crux being a balancy lieback past a bolt. Higher, easier moves lead to a stance below an impressive roof which despite appearances from afar goes easily with a perfect hand crack splitting it.

Belay from gear (pro to 2.5") and walk off or use the anchors on the neighboring

Rollercoaster

and don't forget to set a directional piece for your follower.

A great route to do at least once every season, this route has a lot of fun moves packed into it's relatively short length. Four stars out of five.
content.location: Located on the northern end of the west face.

climbs.name: POS Arete
climbs.fa: Chris Miller, Karen Roseme and Derrick Reineg, May 1998

content.description: Despite initial appearances, this grainy and loose arete is not worth climbing. Minus two stars out of five!
content.location:
Located on the face just left of

Keep the Ball Rolling

.

content.description:
This southwest facing route, located about 75' south of the other Rollerball formation climbs, was originally rated 10d. However, key holds have broken off, rendering the route an "11."

Begin under a steep face beneath the first of three bolts. Use discontinuous seams, edges, and horizontals enroute to the anchors. Very good climb, 3 out of 5 stars.
content.protection:
QD's for three bolts and small camming units for discontinuous seams / horizontals.

Two bolt anchor is at top.

content.description: There's a couple of fun moves off some jugs and crimps in the first 25 feet or so.  The climb then continues up and to the right, following a crack-ish system up a slab with some friction moves on grit.  Nothing spectacular but kinda maybe worth it if in the area?
content.protection: Light single rack is plenty.  You can walk over to the Rollercoaster rap for decent.
content.location: Around the corner to the right of Rollerball.  A broken vertical face about 25 feet high with an obvious jug 2/3rds the way up.
